intro: Paraeremostachys dshungarica, commonly known as the Mongolian grass, is a perennial herb native to the steppes of Central Asia. It typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters and has narrow, grass-like leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, pale blue or purple flowers arranged in dense spikes, which bloom in late summer. It is well adapted to dry, windy conditions and is often found in open grasslands and along riverbanks. This species plays an important role in stabilizing soil and supporting local wildlife in its native habitat.
